continue

continue
1.content: We weren't doing anything that afternoon. In fact, we were freshly fired from our jobs at the laundrymat and the Paco Taco. So we left home, hit the road with nothing to lose, eighty bucks apiece, two acoustic guitars and the world was ours to discover.... As youthfulness goes, we were pretty much the epitome of that. Invincible and young with nothing to worry about except which way the wind seemed to be blowing...
1.title: Intro

choices: Sherry either joins the boys, or she doesn't.
They stay in town, or they go elsewhere.
11.content:
With the three of us sitting there cooling our heels in the parking lot of a 7-Eleven; I sat and mused about how grand our adventures would be. I looked over at Sherry. She sat on the curb with her knees to her chest, humming a sad, little lament. I recognized the song so I put down my Dr Pepper and offered up a some accompaniment on guitar.

Sherry sang, I strummed and Mike kept the beat with his foot, as he smiled at us through a mouth full of Twinkie.

Who's that out on the road?
are you, gonna toe that line?
I wear this ball and chain
any time I'm Blind."


A couple of people stopped to listen, and when we finished playing; they smiled and gave us money.

"Hey", said Mike. "They gave us money". He deftly tuned his fat-bottomed Epiphone and began playing a catchy reggae thing in G.

We played for a couple of hours more, but never with the same success as our first song. I thought about where we could go play where maybe we could get a little more money. So far two hours of playing in a parking lot had netted us 10.36 in change. Ten bucks and change was a start, but I had been getting paid more at the Paco Taco. It was heartening, however, that we could make lunch money off an impromptu jam session. I mused about bigger and better venues. At least I didn't have to say "Welcome to Paco Taco, would you like mild or hot sauce with your muy bueno burrito" anymore.
11.title: Chapter One - Muy Bueno Burrito

choices: They have a good time.
They have a bad time.
111.content:
Sherry went home and Mike and I decided to leave the 7-Eleven for happier hunting grounds. It was still early in the evening, and walking down the road was hot work. We passed a small, white shack with the name ‘Beverly’s’ spray painted over the door. We could hear The Doobie Brothers’ ‘Takin’ it to the Street’ inside. As if on cue Mike and I both suggested we go in for a drink at the same time.

Beverly’s was mostly empty. We made our way to the bar. The barkeep didn’t look like any Beverly I’d ever run across.

“ID”? He asked.

I reached into my pocket and put a twenty on the bar. “Sir, Your establishment enticed us in. We were hot and thirsty, and the righteous tunes we heard beckoned us. We do not wish to inconvenience you , but as you may have guessed we have no ID. We don’t need to stay long, just a couple of Heinekens and a drink for your gracious self”.

“The barkeep gave me casual glance, grunted, then pulled down two glasses from the shelf. He collected a bottle of unmarked brown stuff, and slammed it down, along with the glasses in front of us. “Boys”., he said. “Truth is I don’t care how old you are, but if your going to drink here you better learn to drink like men.” He filled us each a glass, set the bottle back down and walked away. At the end of the bar he picked up a tumbler full of the brown stuff, took a long pull, shook his mangy head and coughed twice. “I already have my own drink”, he wheezed back at us. “You know I can’t sell you no liquor, but I ain’t selling you any”. He stuffed my twenty into his pocket. “This ain’t for the booze. This pays for some advice.”

“Advice”? I managed to get out between spasms.

“Yup”. He answered. “I’d lay off that fancy talk before the regulars show up, and never, ever pet a burning dog”.

The spasms subsided, but the tears kept streaming down my face. Mike’s face was as red as an apple.

“What is this stuff”? Mike asked.

“Not that we’re complaining”. He quickly added.

“It’s a homebrew my Pa makes.” The barkeep answered. “That’s why I can’t sell it to you. It would be illegal, but your welcome to drink as much as you like. I’ve got barrels full of it”.

The thunder from what sounded like a hundred or so Harley’s set the glasses behind the bar to clinking.
111.title: Beverly's

choices: stay out of trouble
get into some trouble
1111.content:
Mike and I looked at each other quickly... These must be 'the regulars'. was the thought we both shared simultaneously. A full blown gang of whiskey drinkin', chain smoking, foul-mouthed bikers.

This, we realized as we raised our eyebrows at each other, could be our first meaningful, cultural experience. A shiver of excitement traveled up my spine, and by the look on his face, it was running up Mike's spine too. We raised our glasses of brown stuff and drained them in unison as the first few members of the motorcycle gang came through the door.
1111.title: Here Come the Regulars

choices: continue
continue
11111.content:
They came in loudly, talking and cursing and joking about something. Then, upon seeing the two of us sitting at the bar, they were suddenly quiet.

Smirking smiles busted out on some of their faces as they swaggered up to us...

A particularly shagging looking guy with big thick white sideburns walked straight up to me.

"Well, well." he said, "Lookey what we have here."
11111.title: Out of our Element

choices: Stop to see the Family
Flip a Coin: East or West?
112.content:
The sun was melting now over the streets... We had long since quit playing... the cold was beginning to set in, and our fingers had gone numb from playing our guitars so long. I kept glancing back to Mike lurking in the shadows behind me, his fingers flicking the ash of a cigarette to the ground. Right now he seemed more absorbed in watching the girls walking across the street than talking to anyone. Sherry was silent as well, her knees tucked up to her chest, chin resting on her hands as she watched the sun sink beneath the horizon. She seemed quiet, musing, buried in her own thoughts... so solomn for how optimistic she usually was.

          "What's on your mind, Sherry?" I asked quietly, not wanting to disturb her thoughts too drastically.

          For a moment there I thought that she wasn't going to answer me. And then, she turned to study me carefully, bright blue eyes piercing in the fading light. "Tell me something," she responded softly. "Do you really want to go back home tonight?"

I heard Mike snort in the backround, sharp exhale of smoke as he bit back a sarcastic comment. We knew that Mike wasn't ever willing to go back home, any night. But as for me...

"No," I told her finally. Even with my family, things were seriously beginning to grate on my nerves... I didn't think I could stand being stagnant much longer.

"What do you think about leaving, then?"

"Leaving to where?" Mike asked suddenly.

Her shrug was nonchalant. "Would it matter? Away."

An impetuous smile grew across his face- i knew he was caught, but i wasn't ready to go just yet.

"Think about it! We wouldn't have to answer to anyone... And we could play for a living, like we did today. We wouldn't get much money, though- but that's the fun of it! We'll never know where we'll sleep next, or where our next gig'll be. It'll just be moving from place to place. No one to answer to- no curfews- no one to tell us what we ought to be doing. What do you say?"

"But what about my family?" I asked. It was a big decision, to just pick up and leave like that, especially if we didn't know when we would return.

"It's your choice," mike told me seriously. "We'll go, right sherry?"
She nodded afffirmation.
"You can tell you parents. Or we can leave right now. Or you don't have to come at all... what'll it be?"
112.title: Going on a Whim

choices: The guy's a filthy bum; call the cops!
The guy's a bum; ask him for weed
It's actually Dick Dale
It's the owner of the joint, drunk out of his mind!
It's a trick by the mind-control alien inside his skull
12.content:
We ran out of cash in El Paso, so while Liz and Jimmy tried to get us gigs, Joel and I had to get jobs at a local conqueso establishment just so we could eat.

One night, after a long day at the drive-through, I was waiting on the last customer, who had just pulled up to the microphone before I could shut off the lights, when Liz and Jimmy knocked on the already-locked front door.

"Can I take your order?" I spoke into the microphone.

The return was a garbled mess of static, because people think they have to yell at the microphone, so all I get is feedback and garbage. I was used to this however, because fast-food places are the same around the globe, so I was able to decipher her order from the junk, "I want a number two, three medium Diet Cokes, and a large Smegma Enchillada, with extra cheese."

"A Smegma Grande, yes?"

"Yes," the woman screamed into the mike; I could probably open the window to hear her, instead of using the damn 35 year-old microphone.

"Anything else?"

"Yes. Two small onion rings."

"Gotcha. Your total is $11.37. Please pull through to the second window."

I put my hand over the mouthpiece and yelled toward the door to Liz and Jimmy, "Joel will let you in, right after he's done cleaning the crapper!"

My headset rang with a very clear and a very startled, "What?"

Damn! I thought my hand had covered the mouthpiece. I quickly spoke into it, "Not you, ma'am. Please pull through."

Joel let our bandmates in as I made the drive-through order. I exchanged her food for the money, made change, and sent her on her way. I was left to close up shop and prep for the coming day.

Liz informed us that they had absolutely struck out at landing us a gig.

We were all disheartened, and after several long moments, Joel quietly asked if we should go home.

I shook my head, "There's nothing for us back there."

Liz nodded, "I agree. We can do this; nobody said it'd be easy."

Jimmy shuffled a foot, "I dunno, man. We're barely scraping by. This may never happen to us, you know?"

There was a light rap on the door. We all looked up to see a guy looking at us expectantly.

I looked at Jimmy, "Didn't you lock the outer doors after Liz and Joel came in?"

He shrugged, "I guess not."

I looked up at the guy and shouted, "We're closed!"

He nodded and spoke; we could kind of hear him through the glass, "I know, but all I have to do is take a leak! My bladder ain't as young and strong as it once was."

He was middle-aged, a little thin on top, slightly pudgy. He was wearing black clothes and a dark headband. I didn't want to let him in to piss all over Jimmy's nice bathroom detail, but I also didn't want him to go out in the parking lot, either. I looked at Liz for advice.
12.title: Closing Time

choices: Use the list to make contacts, set up a meeting
Sell the guitar on E-bay and score some pot
123.content:
"Ah, let 'em in," Liz said, and I walked over to the doors and unlocked them. Once the guy was inside, I pointed him down the hall toward the men's room.

"Thanks, Dude," he hustled off.

I returned to my bandmates and discussed our financial problems while i cleaned the kitchen and shut down all the kitchen equipment, "You gotta believe it'll happen, guys. Nobody's gonna just walk in here and hand us a recording contract. We gotta start small, build a fan base, work from the bottom."

The others were still quiet, and still unconvinced, "I guess."

I was into the whole "rah-rah" speech now. I paced in front of them and waved my arms around my head, occasionally striking a fist in the air, "We gotta believe in each other and believe in the music. What we are doing is worthwhile, and we gotta hold on to it, embrace it, and let the hard times make us stronger!"

The rest of them were silent, but I heard movement behind me. I looked to see the headband-wearing dude was leaning against the corner. He said, "I heard your speech."

"Oh? What'd you think?"

He smiled. The creases around his eyes deepened as he did so, but his eyes looked thirty years younger, "Oh, to be young and ignorant again."

He turned to leave, but said something on the way out, "That was really nice of you guys to let me use the john; I appreciate it. I'd love and chat with you young rock-and-rollers, but my bus is waiting for me. We had to stop cuz one of my guys was in the can. Can you believe that? My own bus and I can't take a whiz!"

As he walked out the door, he turned for one final message, "Oh! And you're right about one thing: no one's ever gonna come walkin' through these doors and just hand you a damn thing, but..." he winked at us,

"Maybe someone might be willing to lend a hand someday."

"Thanks, buddy," we waved him off. Jimmy and I cleaned out back while Joel and Liz swept out front and filled the napkin dispensers.

The lights were out, and the four of us walked out the doors, remembering to lock both sets this time, when Liz noticed the strangest thing, "Hey, you guys! Look at this!"

Resting against the side of the building was an autographed Les Paul guitar with a note taped to the neck. It read:

"Dear kids,
Thanks for lettin' an old fart use your john, it was very kind. I meant what I said about lending a hand. Maybe this helps."

And signed underneath, "Dick Dale."

Beneath that sheet was another that had the phone numbers and addresses for a couple dozen different rock and roll agents, record companies, and bars that might be willing to give us a listen, if we wanted them to hear us badly enough.

"Wow," Jimmy said. Jimmy was our guitarist, and obviously a kindred spirit,

"Dick Dale rules."

Nobody could disagree.
123.title: A Rousing Speech

choices: The cops pull you over.
You form a band with the man.
You go 'home' with the man.
You see your own photo in the next day's newspaper.
Something else.
13.content:
To start with, we weren't quite sure where we were headed.

"I know," said Tanya. "Let's thumb ourselves a lift - we'll go wherever they're going, whoever stops first and can accommodate all of us."

That was as good an idea as any, so we did just that. Of course, it took a while. Most people just zoomed past, a group of youngsters with two guitars and about a zillion tattoos between them was not exactly a pleasing sight for any passing driver.

Finally, this truck pulled up and a cheery face looked out. "Where you kids headed?"

"Wherever you are," we chorused, climbing in before he could react.

"Me?" he said, as we made ourselves comfortable at the back - not a difficult thing to do, since he was apparently delivering furniture somewhere so we actually found a chair each. "You kids are going where I'm headed? Well, kids I'm going home, that's where. I'll tell you what. Play me a tune, and I'll sing to it."

So we played him a tune, and the man sang. Boy, could he sing. What a rich baritone.

"I ain't had no luck
Driving his here truck
So I'm going home.
I'm going home.
I got kids at the back
They're strumming a tune
You look at their eyes
You see the moon.
But I'm going home
I'm going home.
Life's been unfair
I got nowhere
So I'm going home
I'm going home."


"Go on," Tanya urged, as he stopped singing. "Go on, please, that's beautiful."

"I don't know the rest of the song," the man said. He had hesitated before replying - could it be - could he have been - well - crying, just a little bit? Nah. There was this big, cheerful grin on his face as he turned for a second to reply to Tanya.

"Whose song is it?" I asked. "I haven't heard it before?"

"Whose song? Well, kids, it's our song. Mine and yours. Yours and mine."
13.title: I'm Going Home

choices: Describe Rod's taco experience
Describe their lastest adventure on the road to New York City.
stuck some dumb city/give up/get jobs at taco bell/laundrymat
Maria falls in love and runs away
finds a gig at a coffee house and stays put...for a while
15.content:
...and the winds were blowing east, northeast.
That's right, New York City was calling us and we started off that very day! Sure, we knew it'd be tough, a lot of songs would have to be sung on corners in towns we'd never heard of, for mere coins. as long as those coins could keep us fed, well we'd keep playing. Rod said he'd even eat tacos again, though everyone knew what happened the last time he ate one. Secretly, Maria and I promised each other to go without rather than let him eat another one.
15.title: New York City!

choices: People cross the street to avoid us or just walk by
Everyone loves us and give us lots of money!
152.content:
*indent* Days pass and then we arrive in Dallas, TX., weary and sunburned. All we want is to find a cheap hotel to hide from the heat and rest our scenery-numb eyes, however, our funds are limited, so we settle for three cups of coffee at a rather plush McDonald's.
Caffeine-injected, we continue on our way, touring the city, but, finding no parks to start up a song in and no local (non-starbucks)coffee shops to get a gig at, nearly decide to join the tons of begger's standing on every exit ramp asking for money. We search around for writing materials and construct a sign, but by the time we're finished it darkness has fallen and it's gotten quite late. Despondan, we sit on a curb and try to regroup.
*indent* Thankfully, Rod spots a free community newspaper which draws our attention to Deep Ellum, the local club scene.
Elated, we speed there immediately, thanking our luck that it's an semi-early Saturday evening. Once there, amidst the swarming mobs of club-hoppers, we set up shop in a choice location and begin to play.
Maria and Rod on guitar, I on vocals.
152.title: Dallas

info.brief_description: Help me create this tale of wanderlust and music!
info.description:
The characters are at least two or three young adults that are pulling up roots and trying to experience the world and their music!

Please pull their adventures in any direction you want to... Have fun with this, but try to keep it relatively serious and plausible, okay? No aliens, gangsters, or PowerRangers, right?
